medium: Woodblock print (nishiki-e); ink and color on paper
portfolio: From Fifty-three Stations by Two Brushes (Sōhitsu gojūsan tsugi 雙筆五十三次)
signed: in toshidama cartouche: 豊國画 {Toyokuni ga} |  廣重画 {Hiroshige ga}
text: The priest Saigyo_ (1118-1190) was a descendant of the aristocratic Fujiwara family but withdrew from courtly circles to lead a religious life. He remained friends with noble poets, however, and was admired for his own verse. Shortly after his death, an imperial poetry anthology known as the Shinkokinshu_ included over ninety of his poems. Here, Kunisada depicts Saigyo_ in a moment of poetic reverie as he views Mount Fuji, illustrated above by Hiroshige as seen through the pine trees as Yoshiwara.
title: Yoshiwara
